etymologies: Middle English (as an astrological term denoting the relative positions of the ‘stars’ (planets), supposed to influence events): via Old French from late Latin constellatio(n-), based on Latin stella ‘star’

definitions: a group of stars forming a recognizable pattern that is traditionally named after its apparent form or identified with a mythological figure. Modern astronomers divide the sky into eighty-eight constellations with defined boundaries.
shortDefinitions: group of stars forming recognizable pattern that is traditionally named after its apparent form

definitions: a group or cluster of related things

examples.text: no two patients ever show exactly the same constellation of symptoms

shortDefinitions: group of associated or similar people or things
